key_points: Rory McIlroy visited Tiger Woods before the WGC-Match Play, following Woods' February car crash.
McIlroy was encouraged by Woods' condition, noting that he was in 'decent spirits' despite the severity of the crash.
McIlroy shared an anecdote about Woods' perspective on major trophies vs. other achievements, highlighting Woods' focus on major wins.
Woods owns 82 PGA Tour event trophies, but according to McIlroy's story, seems to prioritize his 15 major trophies.
The conversation revealed Woods' selective valuation of tournament wins, emphasizing the importance he places on majors.
McIlroy expressed admiration for Woods' legacy and competitive mindset, emphasizing the impact of Woods on his own career.
McIlroy hopes for Woods' recovery and sees a possibility of Woods returning to competitive golf, perhaps for the 2022 Masters.
Justin Thomas, another pro golfer, also visited Woods and shared his disappointment about Woods missing the Masters.
Thomas mentioned the inspiration he and other younger golfers draw from Woods, highlighting a sense of community among players.
McIlroy sees a collective responsibility among golfers to support Woods and aid his return to the sport.
